title: Sports Lingo
description: Can you decode these sports terms and expressions?

questions.question: In baseball, what is a 'home run'?
options: Running to first base
A run scored from stealing a base
The final run of the game
A hit that allows the batter to circle all bases and score
questions.explanation: A home run is a hit in baseball where the batter successfully circles all four bases and scores a run, typically by hitting the ball over the outfield fence. It is one of the most exciting plays in the sport.

questions.question: In basketball, what does 'slam dunk' mean?
options: A bounce pass to a teammate
A long-distance shot
A shot where the player jumps and pushes the ball down through the hoop
A free throw attempt
questions.explanation: A slam dunk is a type of basketball shot in which a player jumps and forcefully pushes the ball downward through the basket with one or both hands. The term is also used metaphorically to mean something that is a sure success.

questions.question: In tennis, what does 'love' mean as a score?
options: Zero points
Match point
A tied score
Fifteen points
questions.explanation: In tennis, 'love' means zero or no points. The origin is debated, but one popular theory suggests it comes from the French word 'l'oeuf' (the egg), as a zero resembles an egg. A score of 'love-love' means neither player has scored.

questions.question: What does the term 'hat trick' traditionally refer to?
options: A magic trick performed at halftime
A penalty kick in soccer
Winning three games in a row
Scoring three goals in a single game
questions.explanation: A hat trick is when a player scores three goals in a single game. The term originated in cricket in the 1850s, when a bowler who took three consecutive wickets was rewarded with a new hat. It is now commonly used in hockey and soccer.

questions.question: In golf, what is a 'birdie'?
options: A score of one under par on a hole
A score of one over par on a hole
A hole-in-one
A score of two under par on a hole
questions.explanation: A birdie in golf is a score of one stroke under par on a hole. For example, completing a par-4 hole in 3 strokes is a birdie. The term originated in the early 1900s in American golf slang, where 'bird' meant something excellent.

questions.question: In boxing, what does 'southpaw' mean?
options: A defensive stance
A knockout punch
The referee's position
A left-handed fighter
questions.explanation: A southpaw is a left-handed boxer who leads with the right hand and foot forward, using the stronger left hand for power punches. The term is also used in baseball for left-handed pitchers and has expanded to mean any left-handed person in sports.

questions.question: In football (soccer), what is an 'offside'?
options: When the ball goes out of bounds
When a player commits a foul
When an attacking player is closer to the goal line than the second-to-last defender when the ball is played
When the goalkeeper leaves the penalty area
questions.explanation: Offside is called when an attacking player is nearer to the opponent's goal line than both the ball and the second-to-last defender at the moment the ball is played to them. This rule prevents attackers from simply waiting near the opponent's goal.

questions.question: In swimming, what is a 'medley' event?
options: A relay race with only two swimmers
A synchronized swimming routine
A race using only one stroke
A race combining multiple swimming strokes
questions.explanation: A medley in swimming is an event that combines all four competitive strokes: butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle. In an individual medley, one swimmer uses all four strokes. In a medley relay, four different swimmers each swim one stroke.

questions.question: In cricket, what does 'wicket' refer to?
options: The batting helmet
The field of play
The ball used in the game
The set of three stumps and two bails that the bowler aims at
questions.explanation: A wicket in cricket is the set of three vertical stumps topped by two horizontal bails at each end of the pitch. The bowler aims to hit the wicket to dismiss the batsman. The term is also used to describe a dismissal itself.

questions.question: What does the expression 'down to the wire' mean in sports?
options: A race or competition decided at the very last moment
A type of fence around a playing field
A penalty for crossing a boundary line
A radio broadcast of a game
questions.explanation: 'Down to the wire' means a contest that is not decided until the very end. The phrase comes from horse racing, where a wire was stretched across the finish line to help determine the winner. A race that was 'down to the wire' was extremely close.

questions.question: In golf, what is an 'albatross' (also called a double eagle)?
options: A score of three under par on a single hole
A score of one under par
A score of two under par
A hole-in-one on a par-3
questions.explanation: An albatross (or double eagle) is a score of three under par on a single hole. For example, completing a par-5 hole in just 2 strokes. It is an extremely rare achievement in golf, much rarer than a hole-in-one.

questions.question: In basketball, what does 'triple-double' mean?
options: Making three consecutive three-point shots
Accumulating double-digit numbers in three of five statistical categories in one game
Playing three overtime periods
Scoring 30 points in a game
questions.explanation: A triple-double occurs when a player accumulates double-digit totals (10 or more) in three of five statistical categories—points, rebounds, assists, steals, and blocks—in a single game. It is considered a mark of exceptional all-around performance.

questions.question: What does the term 'Grand Slam' mean in tennis?
options: Winning five consecutive matches
Scoring a perfect game without losing a point
Winning a single major tournament
Winning all four major tournaments in a calendar year
questions.explanation: A Grand Slam in tennis refers to winning all four major championships—the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open—within a single calendar year. Very few players have achieved this feat in the history of the sport.

questions.question: In horse racing, what is a 'furlong'?
options: A type of horse breed
The starting gate
A unit of distance equal to one-eighth of a mile
A type of racing saddle
questions.explanation: A furlong is a unit of distance equal to one-eighth of a mile (220 yards or approximately 201 meters). It is the standard unit used to measure race distances in horse racing. The word comes from 'furrow long,' the length of a furrow in a plowed field.

questions.question: In fencing, what does 'touche' (touché) mean?
options: An acknowledgment that a hit has been scored
A defensive parry
The starting command for a match
A missed attack
questions.explanation: 'Touché' is used in fencing to acknowledge a valid hit or touch scored by an opponent. The French word means 'touched.' In everyday language, 'touché' is used to acknowledge that someone has made a clever or valid point in an argument.
